inscription:
Lettered at lower right: CZINMON and on the column at right: ICH LEB VON DER BRUST MEINER DOCHTER

on back in pencil: (various numbers)
provenance: John E. Andrus III, Wayzata, Minn. (until d. 2012); by descent to his daughter, Julie Andrus, Minneapolis, Minn. (2012–18; given to Mia)
text: This type of image is called Roman Charity. It is based on a story related by Valerius Maximus, who was active the second to fourth decades C.E. Cimon was a man imprisoned and condemned to death by starvation. His adult daughter saved his life by secretly breastfeeding him. This act was considered an honorable expression of the greatest love for one’s elders. The vertical German inscription may be translated as “I live from the breast of my daughter.”
title: Cimon and Pero
